pageContext.claim: “I've worked and invoked the Defense Production Act over 100 times to manufacture essential supplies in the United States.”
pageContext.analysis: Under fire from Joe Biden for not using the Defense Production Act enough, Trump suddenly embraced the law and claimed he did use it effectively. But the Congressional Research Service found the administration’s use of the act was “sporadic and relatively narrow.” A CRS reported said that most of the $1 billion that Congress allocated under the Cares Act for purchases of medical equipment and protective gear under the Defense Production Act was shifted to the Defense Department, which spent most of the money — $688 million — on semiconductors, shipbuilding and space surveillance. Trump hailed the release of a White House report that claimed that Trump has wielded the act nearly 80 times to alleviate shortages of masks and other medical supplies. "Yet all but six of the examples cited in the report were either executive orders unrelated to the production of medical equipment or Defense Department expenditures that do not address the nation’s supply shortages," the New York Times said.
